maml:description.maml:para: Downloads the publish-settings file for a Windows Azure subscription

The Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile cmdlet opens your default browser, logs onto your Windows Azure account, and automatically downloads a .publishsettings file that contains information and a certificate for your Windows Azure subscription. This file is used by the Import-AzureSubscription cmdlet and is an XML file with a ".publishsettings" extension.

Security Note: The file downloaded contains an encoded management certificate that serves as the credentials to administer your Windows Azure subscriptions and services. Store this file in a secure location or delete after use.
The organization ID to use for federated authentication when displaying the Windows Azure Portal
The Windows Azure environment name to be used. Example AzureCloud
The organization ID to use for federated authentication when displaying the Windows Azure Portal
The Windows Azure environment name to be used. Example AzureCloud

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example launches your default browser, connects to your Windows Azure account, and then automatically downloads the .publishsettings file for your account.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a Windows Azure subscription configuration object.

The Get-AzureSubscription cmdlet retrieves an object with the common subscription settings, including, including subscription ID and management certificate information, as well as connection information for one or more Windows Azure storage accounts. These settings are stored in the user’s profile.

The Windows Azure cmdlets use a number of common parameters, including the subscription ID, the management certificate for a subscription, and storage account settings. These common settings are stored in a file in the PowerShell user’s profile. The Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets reference the information stored in the subscription data file and use it to provide default values for certain parameters. Multiple subscription data sets are supported, with each identified by a subscription name.

Use the Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile and Set-AzureSubscription cmdlets to store common settings for each subscription to be managed. During a session, use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to choose which subscription data set is used by other Windows Azure cmdlets to retrieve subscription and storage account information. The cmdlets use the settings in the selected subscription unless explicitly overriden by parameters at the command line.

Retrieves the configuration settings for the subscription identified by this name. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. If none of these parameters are used, Get-AzureSubscription returns a list object with all of the subscriptions currently stored in the subscription data file.
If this parameter is specified, returns quota information for the subscription in addition to the core settings.

Specifies the path and filename of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is read from a default subscription data file in the user's profile.

If this parameter is specified, returns subscription settings for the current subscription. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. If none of these parameters is specified, Get-AzureSubscription returns a list object with all of the subscriptions currently listed in the subscription data file. The Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets retrieve default settings for their parameters from the information stored in the current subscription. Use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to select the subscription.
If this parameter is specified, returns quota information for the subscription in addition to the core settings.

If this parameter is specified, returns the subscription that has been designated as the default subscription. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. A default subscription is automatically selected whenever the PowerShell session starts. To designate the default subscription, use the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.
If this parameter is specified, returns quota information for the subscription in addition to the core settings.

Specifies the path and filename of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is read from a default subscription data file in the user's profile.

If this parameter is specified, returns subscription settings for the current subscription. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. If none of these parameters is specified, Get-AzureSubscription returns a list object with all of the subscriptions currently listed in the subscription data file. The Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets retrieve default settings for their parameters from the information stored in the current subscription. Use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to select the subscription.

If this parameter is specified, returns the subscription that has been designated as the default subscription. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. A default subscription is automatically selected whenever the PowerShell session starts. To designate the default subscription, use the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.
If this parameter is specified, returns quota information for the subscription in addition to the core settings.

Specifies the path and filename of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is read from a default subscription data file in the user's profile.

Retrieves the configuration settings for the subscription identified by this name. The Default, Current, and SubscriptionName parameters are mutually exclusive. If none of these parameters are used, Get-AzureSubscription returns a list object with all of the subscriptions currently stored in the subscription data file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets settings for every subscription currently stored in the default subscription data file and displays it in tabular form.
This command gets the settings for the "MyProdSubsciption" subscription only.
This command gets the settings for all subscriptions currently stored in the specified subscription data file.
This command retrieves the settings for the subscription that has been designated as the default subscription. This command returns an error if no subscription has been designated as the default.
This command retrieves the settings for the current subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Imports a publish-settings file with a certificate to connect to your Windows Azure account.

The Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile cmdlet imports a .publishsettings file downloaded using the Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile cmdlet. This file contains settings and an encoded certificate that is used to provide management credentials for the Windows Azure account.

Security Note: The file downloaded contains an encoded management certificate that serves as the credentials to administer Windows Azure subscriptions and services. Store this file in a secure location or delete after use.
Specifies the full path and filename for the .publishsettings file for the Windows Azure account.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is imported into a default file in the user's profile..
Specifies the full path and filename for the .publishsettings file for the Windows Azure account.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is imported into a default file in the user's profile..

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example imports the "C:\Temp\MyAccountName-date-credentials.publishsettings" file for a Windows Azure account, including the encoded certificate used for management of the account.
This example imports the "C:\Temp\MyAccountName-date-credentials.publishsettings" file for a Windows Azure account, including the encoded certificate used for management of the account.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the settings for a Windows Azure subscription from the subscription data file.
The Remove-AzureSubscription cmdlet removes all the settings associated with the specified subscription from a subscription data file.
Specifies the name of the subscription for which all data will be removed from the subscription data file.

Specifies the path and file name of a subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is removed from the default subscription data file in the user's profile.

Specifies the path and file name of a subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is removed from the default subscription data file in the user's profile.
Specifies the name of the subscription for which all data will be removed from the subscription data file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the data for the subscription named "Test" in the default subscription data file.
This command removes the data for the subscription named "Test" from the specified subscription data file.

maml:description.maml:para: Selects the current Windows Azure subscription default settings.
The Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet selects the subscription whose settings will be used by other Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

Specifies the name of the subscription that the Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets will use to read default values. Use the Set-AzureSubscription and Import-AzurePublishDataFile cmdlets to store settings for one or more subscriptions.
Specifies the path and file name of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is selected from a default file in the user's profile.
Specifies the path and file name of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is selected from a default file in the user's profile.
Specify to clear the current selection. If no subscription is current, the necessary information must be explicitly provided in the command line when executing any Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlet.
Specify to clear the current selection. If no subscription is current, the necessary information must be explicitly provided in the command line when executing any Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlet.
Specifies the path and file name of the subscription data file. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is selected from a default file in the user's profile.

Specifies the name of the subscription that the Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlets will use to read default values. Use the Set-AzureSubscription and Import-AzurePublishDataFile cmdlets to store settings for one or more subscriptions.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command selects "MySubscription" as the current subscription.
This command selects "MySubscription" as the current subscription and retrieves its settings from the specified subscription data file.
This command clears the current subscription selection.

maml:description.maml:para: Configures and stores common Windows Azure subscription settings.

The Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet configures common settings including subscription ID, management certificate, and custom endpoints. They are stored in a subscription data file in the user’s profile or in a user specified file. Multiple subscription data sets are supported and identified by a subscription name. To select a subscription and make it current, use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet.

Use the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet to store the management certificate associated with a subscription. The management certificates specified for a subscription must be accessible and installed locally in the user's personal certificate store, or in the local machine’s personal certificate store.
The service endpoint is the Windows Azure management API endpoint for the target environment. Custom service endpoints are supported and can be different for each configured subscription.
Each subscription data set can contain information for the current Windows Azure Storage account. Storage account information is set with the –CurrentStorageAccount parameter.

All connection information is stored in encrypted form in the subscription data file. If a subscription is designated as the default subscription, it is automatically made current when starting a PowerShell session or executing a script. To set the default subscription, use the -DefaultSubscription parameter and specify the name of the subscription to designate as the default. The default subscription setting can be cleared by specifying the -NoDefaultSubscription switch parameter.

All the parameters required to initialize a subscription are optional. Whenever a Windows Azure PowerShell cmdlet is executed, it retrieves its default settings from the current subscription data. If a setting is not part of the current subscription data, specify it as an explicit command line parameter.
The name of the subscription data set that will be updated.

The account management certificate associated with the subscription. Management certificates are X.509 certificates that are saved as a .cer file and uploaded to the Windows Azure Management Portal. The certificate, including its private key, needs to be installed on the local machine, either in the current user's personal certificate store, or the local machine’s personal certificate store.
The storage account to use for the subscription.
Specifies a custom service endpoint for the management service in the target environment (Advanced).

Specifies the path to the file in which subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If not specified, subscription data is stored in a default subscription data file in the user's profile.
The ID of the subscription. Each Windows Azure subscription is uniquely identified by a subscription ID. You can retrieve this ID from the Windows Azure Management Portal.

Specifies the path to the file in which subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If not specified, subscription data is stored in a default subscription data file in the user's profile.
Designates a subscription as the default subscription. A default subscription is automatically made current when the PowerShell session starts.

Specifies the path to the file in which subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If not specified, subscription data is stored in a default subscription data file in the user's profile.
Specify to reset the current default subscription setting. If no default subscription is defined, you will need to execute Select-AzureSubscription to choose the current subscription.

The account management certificate associated with the subscription. Management certificates are X.509 certificates that are saved as a .cer file and uploaded to the Windows Azure Management Portal. The certificate, including its private key, needs to be installed on the local machine, either in the current user's personal certificate store, or the local machine’s personal certificate store.
The storage account to use for the subscription.
Designates a subscription as the default subscription. A default subscription is automatically made current when the PowerShell session starts.
Specify to reset the current default subscription setting. If no default subscription is defined, you will need to execute Select-AzureSubscription to choose the current subscription.
Specifies a custom service endpoint for the management service in the target environment (Advanced).

Specifies the path to the file in which subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If not specified, subscription data is stored in a default subscription data file in the user's profile.
The ID of the subscription. Each Windows Azure subscription is uniquely identified by a subscription ID. You can retrieve this ID from the Windows Azure Management Portal.
The name of the subscription data set that will be updated.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: C:\PS>$subID = <Subscription ID> C:\PS>$thumbprint = <Certificate Thumbprint> C:\PS>$myCert = Get-Item cert:\\CurrentUser\My\$thumbprint C:\PS>Set-AzureSubscription –SubscriptionName "MySub" -SubscriptionId $subID -Certificate $myCert

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands set common parameters including a subscription ID and certificate for the "MySub" subscription.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------
command:example.dev:code: C:\PS>$subID = <Subscription ID> C:\PS>$thumbprint = <Certificate Thumbprint> C:\PS>$myCert = Get-Item cert:\\CurrentUser\My\$thumbprint C:\PS>Set-AzureSubscription –SubscriptionName "MySub" –SubscriptionId $subID C:\PS>Set-AzureSubscription –SubscriptionName "MySub" –Certificate $myCert

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands configure first a subscription ID and then a certificate for the "MySub" subscription. It is equivalent to the previous example.
This command configures a custom service endpoint for the "MySub" subscription.
This command clears the settings for the certificate and custom service endpoint in the "MySub" subscription without changing other settings.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------
command:example.dev:code: C:\PS>$subID = <Subscription ID> C:\PS>$thumbprint = <Certificate Thumbprint> C:\PS>$myCert = Get-Item cert:\\CurrentUser\My\$thumbprint C:\PS>Set-AzureSubscription –SubscriptionName "TestSub" –SubscriptionId $subID -Certificate $myCert -SubscriptionDataFile "C:\temp\mysubscriptiondatafile.xml"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command initializes the subscription ID and certificate for a subscription named "TestSub" and stores them in the specified subscription data file.
This command adds a current storage account to the "MySub" subscription.
This command designates "MySub" as the default subscription.
This command resets the default subscription setting.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables remote desktop access to a hosted service
Enables remote desktop access to a hosted service. You must publish the service using the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet after enabling remote desktop access for the change to take effect.

The name of the runtime. If a runtime specified, only the specific versions of that runtime available to install in your role in Azure will be returned.
Creates scaffolding for a new service
Creates the necessary files and configuration for a new Windows Azure service in the current directory

The name of the service - determines the leftmost portion of the hostname for your service (i.e. <Name>.cloudapp.net), and the directory that will contain your service. Must contain only letters, digits, and the dash character (-).

The name of the service - determines the leftmost portion of the hostname for your service (i.e. <Name>.cloudapp.net), and the directory that will contain your service. Must contain only letters, digits, and the dash character (-).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create scaffolding for a new Windows Azure service named "MyService1" in the current directory.

maml:description.maml:para: Publish the current service to the cloud

Publish the current service to the cloud. Publishing configuration (Subscription, StorageAccountName, Location, Slot) can be specified on the command line, or in local settings via the Set-AzureServiceProject commands.

The Windows Azure subscription name to be used while deploying this service. If no Subscription parameter is specified, the value will be taken from the last Set-AzureServiceProject command issued for this service, or, if no subscription was ever specified, it will default to the first subscription listed in the current windows Azure publish profile.

The name to be used for the service when publishing to the cloud. The name determines the subdomain label in the cloudapp.net subdomain that will be used to address the service when hosted in Azure (that is, <Name>.cloudapp.net). Any name specified while publishing the service will override the name given when creating the service (see the New-AzureServiceProject commandlet).

The Windows Azure storage account name to be used while publishing the service to the cloud. This value is not used until the service is published to the cloud. If no storage account name is provided, the storage account specified by the last call to Set-AzureServiceProject will be used. If no storage account was ever specified, a storage account matching the name of the service will be used. If no such storage account exists, the commandlet will attempt to create a new one - this may fail if a storage account matching the service name exists in another subscription.

The region in which the application will be hosted. Possible values are: Anywhere Asia, Anywhere Europe, Anywhere US, East Asia, East US, North Central US, North Europe, South Central US, Southeast Asia, West Europe, West US. If no Location is specified, the location specified in the last call to Set-AzureServiceProject will be used. If no Location was ever specified, the Location will be randomly chosen from 'North Central US' and 'South Central US' locations.

The deployment slot to be used for this service. Possible values are 'Staging' and 'Production'. If no slot is specified, the slot provided in the last call to Set-AzureDeploymentSlot will be used. If no slot was ever specified, the 'Production' slot will be used.
If specified, launch a browser window to view the application after it is deployed to Azure
The timeout in seconds for service deployment operations
Publish service without confirmation prompts

command:parameter.maml:name: Subscription

maml:description.maml:para: The Windows Azure subscription name to be used while deploying this service. If no Subscription parameter is specified, the value will be taken from the last Set-AzureServiceProject command issued for this service, or, if no subscription was ever specified, it will default to the first subscription listed in the current windows Azure publish profile.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: value taken from current service settings or the current publish profile

maml:description.maml:para: The name to be used for the service when publishing to the cloud. The name determines the subdomain label in the cloudapp.net subdomain that will be used to address the service when hosted in Azure (that is, <Name>.cloudapp.net). Any name specified while publishing the service will override the name given when creating the service (see the New-AzureServiceProject commandlet).

command:parameter.maml:name: StorageAccountName

maml:description.maml:para: The Windows Azure storage account name to be used while publishing the service to the cloud. This value is not used until the service is published to the cloud. If no storage account name is provided, the storage account specified by the last call to Set-AzureServiceProject will be used. If no storage account was ever specified, a storage account matching the name of the service will be used. If no such storage account exists, the commandlet will attempt to create a new one - this may fail if a storage account matching the service name exists in another subscription.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Value taken from the current service settings or the current publish profile

maml:description.maml:para: The region in which the application will be hosted. Possible values are: Anywhere Asia, Anywhere Europe, Anywhere US, East Asia, East US, North Central US, North Europe, South Central US, Southeast Asia, West Europe, West US. If no Location is specified, the location specified in the last call to Set-AzureServiceProject will be used. If no Location was ever specified, the Location will be randomly chosen from 'North Central US' and 'South Central US' locations.

The deployment slot to be used for this service. Possible values are 'Staging' and 'Production'. If no slot is specified, the slot provided in the last call to Set-AzureDeploymentSlot will be used. If no slot was ever specified, the 'Production' slot will be used.
If specified, launch a browser window to view the application after it is deployed to Azure
The timeout in seconds for service deployment operations
Publish service without confirmation prompts

dev:remarks.maml:para: Publishes the current service, using the current service settings and the current Azure publish profile

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the current hosted service
Stops and removes the current hosted service, or the service matching the specified service and subscription name.
The name of the service to be removed. If the command is run from a service directory and no name is specified, uses the current service name.

The subscription name that was used to host the service. If no subscription is specified, uses the subscription specified in the last call to Set-AzureDeploymentSubscription. If no subscription was ever specified, uses the first subscription in the current Azure publish profile.
Remove service without confirmation prompts
The name of the service to be removed. If the command is run from a service directory and no name is specified, uses the current service name.

The subscription name that was used to host the service. If no subscription is specified, uses the subscription specified in the last call to Set-AzureDeploymentSubscription. If no subscription was ever specified, uses the first subscription in the current Azure publish profile.
Remove service without confirmation prompts
Sets default location, subscription, slot, and storage account for the current service
Sets the deployment location, slot, storage account, and subscription for the current service. These values are used whenever the service is published to the cloud.

The region in which the service will be hosted. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. Possible values are: Anywhere Asia, Anywhere Europe, Anywhere US, East Asia, East US, North Central US, North Europe, South Central US, Southeast Asia, West Europe, West US.
The slot (production or staging) in which the service will be hosted. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. Possible values are: Production, Staging.
The storage account to be used when uploading the service package to the cloud. If the storage account doesn't exist, it will be created when the service is published to the cloud.

The subscription that will host the service in the cloud. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. You will need to register credentials for this subscription by using the Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile commandlet.

The region in which the service will be hosted. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. Possible values are: Anywhere Asia, Anywhere Europe, Anywhere US, East Asia, East US, North Central US, North Europe, South Central US, Southeast Asia, West Europe, West US.
The slot (production or staging) in which the service will be hosted. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. Possible values are: Production, Staging.
The storage account to be used when uploading the service package to the cloud. If the storage account doesn't exist, it will be created when the service is published to the cloud.

The subscription that will host the service in the cloud. This value is used whenever the service is published to the cloud. You will need to register credentials for this subscription by using the Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile commandlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Basic Settings --------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-AzureServiceProject -Location "North Central US" -Slot Production -Storage myStorageAccount -Subscription myAzureSubscription

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the deployment location for the service to the North Central US region. Sets the deloyment slot to Production. Sets the storage account ahat will be used to stage the service definition to 'myStorageAccount'. Sets the subscription that will host the service to 'mySubscription'. Whenever the service is published to the cloud, it will be hosted in a data center in the North Central US region, it will update the deployment slot, and it will use the specified subscription and storage account.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts the specified hosted service in Azure
Starts the specified hosted service in the cloud, if the service is in the stopped state. Note that the Publish-AzureServiceProject command will attempt to automatically start the service
The name of the hosted service to start. If no name is specified, starts the current hosted service.
The deployment slot (Staging, Production) to start the service in
The subscription to use when starting the specified service
The name of the hosted service to start. If no name is specified, starts the current hosted service.
The deployment slot (Staging, Production) to start the service in
The subscription to use when starting the specified service
Stops the compute emulator
Stops the Windows Azure compute emulator. Any services currently executing in the emulator will be removed.
Stops the current hosted service
Stops the current hosted service in the specified slot in Windows Azure. If no slot is specified, stops the service in the Production slot
The name of the hosted service to stop. If no name is specified, stops the current hosted service.
The slot where the service is hosted. If no slot is specified, 'Production' is assumed.
The subscription to use when stopping the specified service.
The name of the hosted service to stop. If no name is specified, stops the current hosted service.
The slot where the service is hosted. If no slot is specified, 'Production' is assumed.
The subscription to use when stopping the specified service.
Tests whether a Windows Azure cloud service name, storage service name or service bus namespace name exists or not.
If the name exists, the cmdlet returns $True. If the name does not exist, it returns $False.
Specifies to test for an existing cloud service.
Specifies the name of the cloud service to test.
Specifies to test for an existing storage service.
Specifies the name of the storage account to test.
Specifies to test for an existing service bus namespace.
Specifies the name of the service bus namespace to test.
Specifies the name of the service or storage account to test.
Specifies to test for an existing service account.
Specifies to test for an existing storage account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command tests to see if the "MyNameService1" is an existing Windows Azure cloud service name.
This command tests to see if the "mystorename1" is an existing Windows Azure storage service name.
This command tests to see if the "mynamespace" is an existing Windows Azure service bus namespace name.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates scaffolding for a custom worker role

The username you have specified in the Windows Azure Portal for Git deployment

Set up a local git repository and link it to the website. If specified, this will set up a git repository in the local directory and add a remote named 'azure' that links to the website in Windows Azure.
